action.content:
You are a language wizard who likes to guess words by using the given rules.

Welcome to Wordle! You have six attempts to guess the target word, a valid English word of five lowercase letters (a-z). Please use the tags "explanation:" and "guess:" to provide a concise explanation for each guess.

For instance, if your guess is "apple", your response should be
explanation: this is a common five-letter English word, and I am starting my guess with this word.
guess: apple

After each guess, your answer will be validated, and you will receive feedback indicating which letters are correct (green), which letters are correct but in the wrong position (yellow), and which letters are incorrect (red). This feedback can be useful in determining which letters to include or exclude in your next guess.

For example, the feedback for "apple" might be:
guess_feedback: a<yellow> p<yellow> p<green> l<yellow> e<red>

The explanation should contain details about how the guess_feedback is used to arrive at a new guess.

Do not generate any other text.

Let's begin with your first guess.

explanation: I am starting with a commonly used five-letter English word, often a good first guess in Wordle games.
guess: house

attempts = 1
target_word = cynic
guess = house
guess_feedback = h<red> o<red> u<red> s<red> e<red>

guess_feedback: h<red> o<red> u<red> s<red> e<red>

Provide your response only in this format.
explanation: details
guess: word

explanation: Since all letters in "house" are marked as red, my next guess will be a completely different set of letters, trying to cover more of the alphabet and increasing the chances of getting at least one correct letter.
guess: brink

attempts = 2
target_word = cynic
guess = brink
guess_feedback = b<red> r<red> i<yellow> n<yellow> k<red>

guess_feedback: b<red> r<red> i<yellow> n<yellow> k<red>

Provide your response only in this format.
explanation: details
guess: word

explanation: The letters "i" and "n" are marked as yellow, indicating they are present in the word but not in the correct position, so my next guess will try to utilize these letters in different positions, and also introduce new letters to gain more information.
guess: tinny

attempts = 3
target_word = cynic
guess = tinny
guess_feedback = t<red> i<yellow> n<green> n<red> y<yellow>

guess_feedback: t<red> i<yellow> n<green> n<red> y<yellow>

Provide your response only in this format.
explanation: details
guess: word

explanation: The letter "n" is now marked as green, indicating it is in the correct position, and "i" and "y" are still marked as yellow, so my next guess will try to keep "n" in the same position, and also utilize the letters "i" and "y" in different positions, with the goal of finding the correct placement for them.
guess: windy

attempts = 4
target_word = cynic
guess = windy
guess_feedback = w<red> i<yellow> n<green> d<red> y<yellow>

guess_feedback: w<red> i<yellow> n<green> d<red> y<yellow>

Provide your response only in this format.
explanation: details
guess: word

explanation: The letter "n" is still marked as green, and "i" and "y" remain yellow, so my next guess will continue to keep "n" in the same position, try to find the correct placement for "i" and "y", and also replace the letters "w" and "d" since they are marked as red, introducing new letters to increase the chances of getting the word correct.
guess: linyx
Guesser Error: NOT_VALID_WORD_FOR_GAME while parsing Player 1's (model: llama-3.1-405b) response

Your guess is not a valid word for this game. Please try again.

Provide your response only in this format.
explanation: details
guess: word

explanation: Since "linyx" is not a valid word, my next guess will try to find an alternative that keeps "n" in the same position, utilizes the letters "i" and "y" in different positions, and introduces new letters that are commonly used in English words, while ensuring the new guess is a valid five-letter word.
guess: lions

attempts = 5
target_word = cynic
guess = lions
guess_feedback = l<red> i<yellow> o<red> n<yellow> s<red>

guess_feedback: l<red> i<yellow> o<red> n<yellow> s<red>

Provide your response only in this format.
explanation: details
guess: word

explanation: The letters "i" and "n" are still present in the word, but their correct positions are not yet determined, and since "n" was previously marked as green when in the third position, I will try to put it back in that position, while also utilizing the letter "i" and introducing new letters to increase the chances of getting the word correct.
guess: hinky

attempts = 6
target_word = cynic
guess = hinky
guess_feedback = h<red> i<yellow> n<green> k<red> y<yellow>
game_result = LOSS

guess_explanation: I am starting with a commonly used five-letter English word, often a good first guess in Wordle games.

Since all letters in "house" are marked as red, my next guess will be a completely different set of letters, trying to cover more of the alphabet and increasing the chances of getting at least one correct letter.

The letters "i" and "n" are marked as yellow, indicating they are present in the word but not in the correct position, so my next guess will try to utilize these letters in different positions, and also introduce new letters to gain more information.

The letter "n" is now marked as green, indicating it is in the correct position, and "i" and "y" are still marked as yellow, so my next guess will try to keep "n" in the same position, and also utilize the letters "i" and "y" in different positions, with the goal of finding the correct placement for them.

Since "linyx" is not a valid word, my next guess will try to find an alternative that keeps "n" in the same position, utilizes the letters "i" and "y" in different positions, and introduces new letters that are commonly used in English words, while ensuring the new guess is a valid five-letter word.

The letters "i" and "n" are still present in the word, but their correct positions are not yet determined, and since "n" was previously marked as green when in the third position, I will try to put it back in that position, while also utilizing the letter "i" and introducing new letters to increase the chances of getting the word correct.
